CONCLUSIÓN 
In the first few weeks in which the news on a new epidemic
of influenza went public, the media analysed here, televisionand press, exhibited a similar behaviour. 
In television, the combination of image and contents (sound
and texts) did not convey the impression of an alarming andserious public health problem on a worldwide scale, while it117ENGLISH VERSION
was also made clear that there was no relationship between
the disease and the consumption of pork. 
In the press, the coverage was similar to television's, since
the greater space available for explaining details made it easierto interpret the information better, hence the end result isapparently less alarmist than on television. The absence ofmoving pictures also helps to dispel alarmism in the informa-tion, even although this was also present in the photographsused. As in television, the press also made a major effort toclarify the non-existence of any risk associated with the con-sumption of pork.
With regard to the alarm generated, the following indicators
are an example of how the news programmes and the pressgradually spread this perception in the audience in the firstweek: with Influenza A. Besides affording prominence to this news
item, it was presented as the news of the day. Overall, it wasgiven an average of more than 10 minutes a day, highlyunusual in a medium where “time is golden” since it has toshare that time with all the other important news items of theday. 
b) Similarly, all the dailies put the topic on the front cover,
assigning up to 12 pages to the topic in a single day. 
c) The pictures that went with all this information consisted
basically of people wearing masks, people at airports andhealth staff. The mask is in itself an image that generates fear,mistrust, it suggests the threat of contagion. Moreover, theperception of threat was heightened by the fact that thosemasks were being worn outside their natural environment(hospitals) and could be seen in the streets, airports, schools(the threat had reached everyday life). In Telecinco the pic-tures were particularly more dramatic than the other chan-nels, with a predilection for pictures of soldiers (figures thatundoubtedly generate the sensation that something unto-ward is occurring) and children with masks (an image thatstirs up emotions in spectators). 
d) The contents of the news programmes in those first few
days of the news item (voices of the anchorperson, corre-spondents and sources, texts in kyron and on the frontpages of dailies) left the spectator in no doubt that the situa-tion was alarming, serious, uncertain and unpredictable.They all made it very clear that there was a possibility that thenew influenza could turn into a pandemic and that it wastherefore necessary to take extraordinary measures.
e) In the press, the headlines also spoke of seriousness, fear,
lack of control and even pandemic (long before it wasdeclared by the WHO). The texts, albeit more cautious, werea constant dribble of data on deaths and people affected.The perception of threat and the seriousness of the situationgenerated by this type of information was compounded laterby a sensation of confusion, derived from the existence ofsome dissonant voices (such as the WHO expert whoclaimed that eating raw pork was dangerous, or talk of con-spiracy plots, or even the first changes in the name of thedisease, which were little more than a reflection of a certainlack of coordination).Despite this general tonic of alarm at the situation, if we
focus on the specific question of information on the risk asso-ciated with the consumption of pork it may be concluded thatthe four channels and the seven dailies studied acted withimpeccable prudence. In a situation that could generate con-fusion among citizens, they all reacted in the same directionwith a view to clarifying any possible unfounded doubts and toavoid raising unnecessary alarms. The observations that leadus to this conclusion are:a) The four channels and the seven dailies quickly abandoned
the "swine flu" name. The public channels' compliance withthe guidelines of the European Commission (first change ofname: from swine flu to new influenza) was immediate. Theprivate channels took somewhat longer to react to the firstchange (only one more day), but they took up the second onequickly (recommended by the WHO, from new influenza toInfluenza A ). It should be mentioned that one of the publicchannels (TV3), while it did cease to use the "swine" expres-sion rapidly, clung on to the second name, new influenza, forlonger, and took longer to talk about Influenza A .
b) Both the texts and the voices (anchorpersons, correspon-
dents, sources) insisted that the risk of eating pork was non-existent (or very low) and that the measures taken in Egyptand Russia were disproportionate.
c) In all the cases, support was sought through opinions
from the authorities and in some cases through expertsfrom the scientific community. Barring some exceptions, inwhich it was said that swine had to be submitted to moreintensive surveillance, or in the case of the WHO expert,who talked about the risk of eating raw meat (declarationquickly retracted by the WHO), both politicians and scien-tists strongly disassociated swine from the concerns gen-erated by this disease. The non-existent risk of eating porkwas made very clear.
d) The pictures were in tune with this message, since on very
few occasions were pigs actually shown when informationwas provided on this news item. In general, pigs only madesporadic appearances, such as the case of the burning ofanimals in Egypt.
Summarising, two lessons can be drawn from this case.
Firstly, the rapid reaction by the administration (particularly theEuropean Commission, since the WHO took somewhat longer)was an example of good communication practices, since itdrew attention away from the pigs in the information on thisdisease. This attitude, driven by the impeccable loyalty of thelocal administrations and an even more admirable obedienceby the media, allayed the citizens' fear of eating pork, and thissector was not affected, unlike other food crises, regardless ofwhether there was a real risk or not. The second lesson to belearned is, nevertheless, more negative. It is the demonstrationof how relatively easy it has become to generate a globalisedstate of alarm in the population. On this occasion, more thanthe actual words or the specific contents of the information, itis the impact of the constant presence of the news item in aprominent place (in the wrap-up or at the beginning of the2009 FSM Report - Food Safety in the Mass Media
118news programme, the cover on a daily, etc.), together with
space-hogging (minutes on television, pages in the press), thusrelegating other possible news items of the day to a secondaryposition.
3.2. Scientific rigour of information sources in food
The objective of this analysis is to study the rigour and degreeof scientific evidence of the information received by society onfood safety questions. More specifically, the topic selected foranalysis was information on food properties, since it is anincreasingly more frequent type of information and one that canchange readers' consumption habits. To perform the analysis,texts that speak more specifically about the safety of the so-called “functional” foods were separated from those thataddress food properties in general. A functional food is regard-ed as one that contains a component, nutrient or non-nutrient,with a selective effect on one or several body functions, with anadded effect on nutritional value and whose positive effects jus-tify the promotion of their functional or even healthy character-istics.
Functional foods
In the course of 2009 there are 6 texts on the food safety offunctional foods, in other words which deal with the benefits orrisks of this type of food. Articles that talk about food proper-ties and which mention functional foods are not included, sincethese texts are addressed in the ‘food properties’ section, andnor are articles that advertise commercial products. This isundoubtedly why there are few articles under this category offunctional foods. Examples of this type of news items are: “TheIRTA manages to obtain milk with omega 3” naturally, July 23,La Vanguardia ; or “Drinking milk is no longer about just drink-
ing milk”, September 22, El País . 
This topic does not appear in all the dailies analysed and
when it does it is sporadically, in supplements or in sectionsrelated to the economy. The texts analysed belonged to thenews programme genre, except one interview, and none ofthem appear on the cover. Most of the texts with informationon functional foods collected express their benefits thanks totheir components and the illnesses they can prevent orimprove, but none of them talk about risk or side effects. Theauthors of these texts are mainly from editorial staff or journal-ists; of the 6 texts, 4 are signed by the editorial office and 2 byjournalists, but there is no expert on functional foods and theirproperties. As regards sources of information, two informationarticles have one or more sources but the rest, except the inter-view, have none. The sources of information that appear inthese texts come particularly from the world of industry (2 ofthe 3 sources that are cited) and only one of the articles refersto scientific sources. These texts therefore do not seem to setout to verify the degree of scientific rigor of information fromindustry (obviously the major stakeholder).
Nevertheless, functional foods enjoy an increasingly greater
presence on the market. As was expressed by a news item inNovember: “more than 80% of the growth in sales of foodproducts to the European market are related to the marketingof food products with functional claims” ( El Diari de Tarragona ,27.11.09). Moreover, the creation of the Tecnoparc in
Tarragona highlights the desire to create centres in Catalonia toinvestigate nutrition and health in order to obtain an economicyield through the creation of functional foods. Thus, Cataloniahas commercial and research in these products, but for themoment its appearance in the press is very sporadic.Moreover, the secondary position of these texts in the dailiesand the fact that they do not appear on the cover leads us tothink that the dailies attach scant importance to them, a factthat might also have affected the negligible effort to verify theinformation.
Food properties The analysis of this topic includes a greater number of arti-
cles, 63, carefully screened. The criteria for including them inthe analysis were that they had to be news items addressingone or more of the following questions: · properties of specific foods or of a group of foods (for
example fruit)
· research intended to demonstrate these properties · diets in which the foods that would justify these properties
are highlighted (for example, the Mediterranean diet) 
· diets or food that are recommended for certain situations
(for example, Christmas or stages in life, such as adoles-cence) 
· diets or food that are recommended for diseases placing
the emphasis on the use of food as a preventive element(for example, wine or olive oil for the prevention of cardio-vascular diseases) or therapeutic element (for example,diets to avoid iron deficiency).
Information on food properties is habitual in all the dailies
analysed, except 20 minutos. The topic is presented through-out the year, while there are times when a higher amount of arti-cles appears (for example, at Christmas or in summer). Themajority genre is the news programme, but there are also opin-ion and interpretation articles (reports), although there are fewof the latter. These texts are to be found in a similar proportionin the inside pages of the dailies and in supplements (53% vs47%, respectively). Nevertheless, this type of information hasgreater visibility and exposure in supplements, with 25% of thetexts on supplement front covers (it should be rememberedthat this proportion is only 5% in the general data base) andwhere texts are longer. Moreover, more expert sources relatedto world of nutrition (33% of the texts) were used in the writingof the articles. 
20% of the texts are unsigned or are signed generally (“edi-
torial staff”), whereas 80% are written by journalists or collab-orators that write regularly on food and health. Half of the arti-cles have at least one source of information, of which 13%have more than 3 sources of information in the text. Due tothe fact that the data base used to analyse the texts onlyincludes detailed information from three first sources of infor-mation located in the text, the results presented below onlyrefer to these first three sources. In contrast to the generalresults of the analysis of the press from 2009 where sources119ENGLISH VERSION
of information from the scientific sphere appear in a minority,
when we analyse this topic, 72% are sources related to thescientific sphere and most of them are research personnel, inother words, scientific experts in the topic in question, and toa lesser degree health staff (doctors, nurses, etc.). In secondplace, we have sources from the world of industry and busi-ness (17%) and a very small number of political sources orfrom civil society. 
The approach to the question of risk in this type of news
items is broader in comparison with the topic of functionalfoods. Of 63 news items, 57 talk about benefits and 44 abouthazards. The global balance of the news items studied is 43positive articles and 20 neutral, there being no negative one.Thus, in general these texts deal with the benefits of food ordiets but also express the possible dangers or negativeeffects, offering a broader and more global vision of the topicaddressed. Moreover, 31 texts (in other words half of them)include recommendations from sources of information ormade directly by the author. To complete the recommenda-tions, some of the texts tend to carry recipes. 
The texts that talk about food properties are treated in
greater depth, with more sources of information, more expertsources, with advice and a more extensive approach to thequestion of risk in comparison with functional food topics ingeneral. Nevertheless, in no case do they address the possi-ble conflict of interests that may exist between the expertscited as a source of information and the different actors thathave an interest in talking positively about a group of foods(companies, cooperatives, etc.). It would be desirable for thejournalist to investigate these possible conflicts of interests sothat the reader can be critical with the information theyreceive. 
Let us look at four examples of articles on functional foods
and food properties in general to reflect upon the matter. Thetexts chosen are representative of the different types of newsitems on food safety and functional foods/food propertiesoften found in the dailies. 
Text 1. The IRTA manages to obtain milk with omega 3 nat-
urally ( La Vanguardia , 23.07.09)
This article is the only one of those collected in the functionalfoods section that includes sources of information from the sci-entific sphere. Therefore, we seek to analyse these sources toascertain the degree of scientific evidence in the text. 
The main source of information is the investigator Àlex Bach,
Director of the Ruminants Unit of the Institute of Food andAgriculture Research and Technology, who has published vari-ous articles on research on milk products in international scien-tific journals of repute. The article cites the journal that pub-lished the results disseminated in the news item, called theJournal of Dairy Science and is the most highly-rated journal inthe science category of lactic products, thus affording credibil-ity to the results the writer publishes in this article. The text alsomentions who will leverage these scientific advances and willmaterialise them in the marketing of this system of productionof milk with omega 3, thus furnishing all the information need-ed for the reader to know who investigated how this milk wasproduced, where it was researched, who rated the degree of
scientific interest and who will subsequently use it to market it. 
This type of articles allows the reader to be critical about
what they are reading thanks to the information provided in thetext. Despite technical jargon, the article is written in a languagethe reader can understand. Therefore, we have no recommen-dations for this text since we think it is a model to be followedin addressing topics related to research and food safety. 
Text 2. The virtues of (raw) garlic ( El País , 10.01.09)
This text was published in the ‘Health’ supplement of El País atthe beginning of 2009. There is more time available for draftingthe texts contained in the supplement (one month in the caseof this supplement) and are often “from the fridge”, in otherwords they do not depend on current events, which renders itpossible for them to be addressed in greater depth. In thiscase, despite the time available to prepare this information andthe space assigned to the topic (a full page), it is surprising thatonly two sources of information are cited. 
The source of information, Francisco Javier Leon, is cited as
a “biochemist and expert in nutrition”, but no explanation ofwhere he works is given nor where we could find him if wewanted more information. Neither did we locate more informa-tion on the Internet, since the name is relatively common andthere are different people that fit the references given by thewriter. The other source, the Department of Agricultural andBotanical Research of the Ministry of Agriculture of the USA, isused to justify the data presented in the table that describesthe components of garlic.
As good journalistic practice it would be advisable to use
more sources of information to verify the data, particularly in atext of one page in a supplement. Clear clues should also begiven so that the interested reader will know the degree ofcredibility of the source and even where to find it. 
Moreover, the article starts by saying that the beneficial
effects of garlic now have ‘scientific backing’, but at no point isreference made to any scientific article or site to find informa-tion with a minimum degree of scientific evidence. Althoughwords or phrases such as ‘it has been scientifically demon-strated’, these claims lack any value if no further information isprovided as to where, when, who has demonstrated this fact(the journal where the scientific article was published, who theinvestigator was, the opinion of the rest of the scientific com-munity, etc.). In fact, if we enter the ‘Pubmed’ web where wecan find articles published in scientific journals of repute, wesee many articles that refer to the healthy properties of garlic.Providing a revision of what has been investigated in these arti-cles would be interesting to afford credence to the informationthat is published. 
Finally, although most of the text is understandable and pro-
vides a great deal of information on the healthy properties ofgarlic, there are paragraphs that use expert language, withspecialised terminology that cannot be understood by theaverage reader, for example the phrase: “the sulphurous com-ponents make it one of the best bactericides”. The use ofresources such as computer graphics or highlighted elementshelps the reader to take in what is being read.1202009 FSM Report - Food Safety in the Mass Media
Text 3. Food helps to regulate growth in adolescents ( ADN,
08.09.09)This text, published in the ADN daily, is an example of a regu-lar section written by Belen Castr o, the nutritional advisor to the
Pascual Sanz Institute, a non-profit making organisation, one ofwhose core objectives is the dissemination of science. Thisinstitute collaborates with different universities, foundations ordailies to promote this work in different areas (science, medi-cine, etc.), even with the Union of Consumers. Its website con-tains scientific articles, reports and information on different top-ics related to nutrition and health. While the objective is the pro-motion of rigorous scientific dissemination based on knowledgeaccepted by the scientific community, the articles published byBelen Castro contains no references to scientific articles,sources of information from this sphere or studies performed onwhich her information is based. Therefore, while the author is anutrition professional, it is not possible to crosscheck the infor-mation she provides. In the field of nutrition there are certain top-ics that are controversial (e.g. the consumption of milk foods),the reason why it would be advisable, on making recommenda-tions or when providing information, to include more clues sothat the reader will know where the information was obtained orwho is providing it. It is positive, however, that an e-mail addressis provided at the end of the article for questions, suggestions,etc., enabling the r eader to expand the information. 
It would therefore be recommendable that despite having
an expert write the text, this expert should back up the articlewith bibliographic references or other sources that afford theinformation greater credibility. This is possible in the case of thesection written by Belen Castro by virtue of the space, sincethe text takes up almost a whole page of the daily. 
Text 4. ‘Wine and health, a booming binomial’ (La
Vanguardia, 17.12.09)The article begins with the phrase: “It has been scientificallydemonstrated that wine ‘drunk in moderation, with constancyand responsibility’ has positive effects on the human body”. Ifwe explore the text we can see that the main sources of infor-mation in it belong to or are strongly linked to the Fundaciónpara la investigación del Vino y la Nutrición (Fivin), a foundationthat has a scientific committee with researchers of repute andwhose board of trustees includes companies such asCodorniu, Freixenet or Bodegas Vega Sicilia. One of its coreobjectives (expressed on its website) is “to be present at con-gresses and national and international symposia where winehas to be defended from the standpoint of food and nutrition”.Thus, we are hardly likely to find information on the negativeeffects of this alcoholic drink with the data provided by thisfoundation. In fact, the article lists the positive effects of wine inrelation to health, backed by scientific studies which only men-tion the centre where they were carried out without explainingwho the investigator was or the group responsible for theresearch or any other reference. No possible negative effects ofwine consumption were mentioned until the end of the article.These are: ‘it causes drowsiness or is not recommendable inpregnant women or diabetics’, in a short piece of text. On the other hand, there are also contradictory messages.
For example one of the specialists quoted, doctor SantiagoDexeus, talks about wine consumption and says that one glassof wine with a meal “should be the acceptable limit in everydayeating”, whereas the photo caption where he can be seen,glass of wine in hand, reads: ‘Santiago Dexeus recommends aglass of wine with every meal’. It is also striking that the opin-ion of this well-known doctor, chairman of honour of Fivin, iscited as a reference warranting credibility, although the special-ity in which he is an undisputed point of reference, gynaecolo-gy and obstetrics, is somewhat removed from the topic inquestion.
One way of improving this type of information would have
been: 1) the sources of information should be cited properlywithout altering the original, without substantial changes; 2) thelink between the source of the information in this text and thecommercial interests of a group of trustees engaged preciselyin the production and distribution of wine should have beenmade clearer, and 3) the sources presented as experts shouldhave been more related to the question, for example, special-ists in nutrition, health experts, cardiologists, hepatologists,specialists in addictions, etc.
3.3. Animal health
2009 was characterised by different health warnings related toanimals. The cases of swine flu, bluetongue disease, Q fever,avian influenza or contaminated fish are but some of the exam-ples addressed in greater detail below. Despite the fact thatnone of these cases have serious consequences for the pop-ulation, they have had economic repercussions. In generalthese topics did not take up a great number of articles,although some of them generated major alarm. 
Bluetongue, back again?
After the bluetongue alarm, a viral disease in sheep and cattlethat hit the livestock sector in 2008, 2009 began with a noticefrom the Department of Agriculture that it was to extend con-trol to prevent and eradicate this disease. Nevertheless, furthercases appeared in Lleida a few months later. The Segre dailyreports on the topic descriptively, without attaching too muchimportance to it and and without talking about any risk forhumans. A couple of months later the same daily announcedeconomic aid from the European Union to eradicate this dis-ease by means of a vaccination campaign to curb the propa-gation of bluetongue. Despite the economic commotion in2008, these news items did not appear on the cover and tookup little space in the daily's pages. Moreover, the sources ofinformation cited are sparse and always political, with no effortmade to find scientific sources that might clarify any doubts orqueries that consumers may have.

The unknown disease that killed sheep and goats and vac-
cination against bluetongue.Halfway through March, different dailies echoed an unknowndisease that killed thousands of goats and sheep in Girona andBarcelona. The livestock breeders believed that it might be dueto an adulterated batch of the vaccination that the Departmentof Agriculture, Food and Rural Action (DAR) gave to the animalsto prevent the bluetongue disease in August 2008. Despite theignorance of the origin of the disease, in the articles, techni-cians, vets and livestock breeders state that it does not affecthuman consumption because these sick animals or deaths donot enter the food chain since the animals are controlled in theslaughterhouses and are withdrawn so that they do not reachthe consumer. The Ministry of the Environment reports thatthere is no link between the deaths and vaccination, that thecondition is neither viral nor infectious and that there is no riskto human health.
The administration took control of the situation and at the
end of March decided to slaughter the animals from the mostaffected farms. It applied what is known as the health vacuumthat consists of the Catalan Government slaughtering the ani-mals, disinfecting the farm and compensating livestock breed-ers. On these dates, the texts talked about the fact that the dis-ease did not seem to get worse and that the measures beingtaken would help to stop it, but its origin had not yet beencleared up. 
At the beginning of April the results of the study carried out
by the Centre for Research in Animal Health (CReSA) attributedthe deaths to environmental, parasitic and management fac-tors, ruling out any relationship between the deaths and thevaccination against bluetongue. Months later, two Catalan live-stock breeders appeared in the media denouncing the Ministryof Agriculture for not providing redress for the damages causedby the disease, which killed animals on farms in Catalonia,Spain and affirming that there is a direct relationship betweenthe death of the animals and the vaccination against blue-tongue. There was no further information on this topic in therest of the year so we shall have to wait for the analysis of 2010to see how this news item, which has reared its head onceagain in the Catalan press, evolves.
This topic appeared several times on front covers, particular-
ly at the beginning and taking up quite a lot of space in the dif-ferent dailies when the topic was treated, even accompaniedby an interview. Although it initially appeared in different dailies,in the end it was published basically in El Punt because thecounties of Girona were the most affected. The sources thatappeared in these texts are basically political and from theadministration, explaining the situation and the measures takenat all times. In general the texts that addressed the topic talkedof risk, with a negative final balance (or in other words, the risksoutweigh the benefits according to the information). More thanhalf of the texts talked explicitly about health warning.
Curiously enough, in 2009 there was an overlap between
this unknown disease that killed goats and sheep and the out-break of Q fever in Holland at the end of the year (December9). While they are two different diseases, the headline of theonline version of El Pais might lead to confusion due to the factthat it affected the same type of animals. The title of the inform-
ative text was “Holland will sacrifice thousands of goats andsheep affected by the greatest worldwide outbreak of Q fever”.This information did not appear in the printed press and wetherefore do not include it in our analysis. Nevertheless, wethought it would be interesting to point out that there may beinformation that could cause confusion among readers takinginto account the fact that this food crisis situation was resolvedmonths later and in a small space in the daily that might gounnoticed by the reader.

Avian influenza hit the headlines in October with alarmist head-lines: “400,000 hens slaughtered after a virus is detected” ( El
Diari de Tarragona ) or “The avian influenza H7 leads to the

ease in the headline but not the subtitle, and the text explainsthat there is no hazard because “it is not the feared H5N1 virusthat affects human beings, but rather H7, as yet undefined butharmless to human beings”. In away, and despite the alarming headlines, the aim was to reas-sure the population by stating that the risk was zero becausethe virus is not transmitted to human beings and neither thehen eggs nor cooked meat involve any hazard. za that affects the animals in an alarming fashion but the newsitem lasts two days and after that it only appears only a coupleof times with regard to countries that do not want to importchicken from Spain in case it is infected such as Hong Kongand Qatar. Sea animals and food unsafety: the case of the catfish
The contamination of fishing and its effect on human health isa recurring topic in the press. In 2009 there are texts relatedto this topics such as “The Foix dam shuts down for fishingdue to contamination” which appears on the front cover ofthe La Vanguardia supplement on March 4. The text talksabout the presence of toxic algae that affect water and fishquality, and fishing was forbidden. Nevertheless, there aregroups of people that poach in these waters and sell theircatch, endangering the food safety of the fish sold due topossible hepatic conditions caused by the intake of this typeof contamination in people. Apart from this and other exam-ples, the most covered case was the catfish, present in theCatalan press in October and November 2009. 
In October, El Pais published a text on the increasingly
greater presence of the catfish in Catalan rivers, an exoticspecies introduced illegally for big game fishing, which canweigh in at more than 200 Kg and measure more than 2metres long. Its voracity threaten biodiversity in these rivers,and since they have no predators they are spreading all the
time. Thus, the Department of the Environment and Housingstarted to plan the eradication of the catfish from the riverEbro through the Mondo Ivans company. This companyexports the frozen fish to Rumania where it is greatly appre-ciated. However, on November 12 the catfish was back in thenews on the cover of El País, and its supplement Catalunya.On this occasion, scientists from the CSIC stated that thesefish were contaminated with high levels of mercury, heavymetals and organochlorated compounds, due to the proxim-ity with the Flix dam, which accumulates tonnes of toxicchemical waste. According to the daily, although the negativeeffects of these compounds on the organism and the dangerof consuming this fish was known by the CatalanGovernment, the marketing of the contaminated catfish fordirect or indirect consumption through meal and animal feedwas not prohibited. In fact, the following day, El País, the dailythat covered this news item most reported that theDepartment of the Environment authorised exports toRumania saying that it was not fit for consumption but couldbe used for meal or feed. According to the daily, it is a seri-ous case of food unsafety, since metals such as mercury tra-verse the organism through the food chain, either throughdirect consumption of the fish or else feed for other animalsthat will be consumed and in which this metal accumulates.Moreover, the daily insists that the Department of theEnvironment recognises that it cannot control the use that willbe made of the catfish by the Rumanian company but thatnevertheless any risk can be ruled out. The fact that scientistsare quoted denouncing the contamination and a possiblehealth risk for consumer, even if it is in Rumania, and where,moreover, people representing the administration appear say-ing that there is no risk, generates distrust and a food safetyconcern. Despite the controversy and seriousness of thistopic, the news item disappears from the press and is notpicked up again in any daily.
The news on this topic takes up a good deal of space in
the dailies in which they are published, in general half a pagedaily on average. The approach to risk is often negative sincewe are dealing with the danger of eating this contaminatedfish and some articles even say that it is a health warning. Ingeneral, these information articles appear in supplements orin sections such as Society or Catalunya, written by editorialstaff and with different sources of information that combinepolitical and scientific sources providing good coverage of theinformation expounded.

4 Conclusions
A relevant topic in the Catalan press
Information related to food safety continued to be present andimportant in the Catalan press in 2009. The number of informa-tion articles related to this topic has increased in comparisonwith the previous year, with the Segre daily containing moretexts and a greater number of front pages on food safety. 
With regard to 2008, we see that although some topics
continue to be newsworthy, the current affairs scenario was dif-ferent. For example, in 2009, one topic that had seldom appe-ared in 2008 appeared with greater frequency in the Catalanpress. More specifically, it was the topic we have called ‘Foodand agriculture sector’, which includes topics that affect thissector such as the current crisis, agrarian policies or produc-tion. On the other hand some topics were present in the pressover these first two years of analysis, such as ‘Food prices’ or‘Economic crisis’. These topics included, more specifically, theprice of the shopping basket, the prices of different foods, howto save on shopping, the creation of three Price Observatoriesspecialised in different products (swine, agriculture and foodand fruit), the prices paid to rural workers and livestock bree-ders for raw materials, etc. Moreover, the ‘food crisis’, definedas the availability of sufficient amount of food, continued to be,as it had been in 2008, another one of the most relevant topics.Finally, it is important to point out that there are hardly any foodcrisis situations in comparison with the previous year (exceptio-nal cases would be the death of sheep and goats in March,swine flu in May or the export of contaminated catfish for con-sumption to Rumania in November). 
The importance of information sources
This report analyses sources of information from different pers-pectives due to the fact that these sources are fundamental inthe subsequent handling of the news item and the rigour of theinformation that is being presented in an informative text. In thefirst place, if we consider that in general the texts that soughtmore in-depth information are those that used different sourcesof information, from different areas and of ‘recognised autho-rity’ (scientists, management or control representatives, etc.),we can conclude that the dailies with the highest circulation arethose which, in general, explore the topics treated in greatestdepth, probably because they have more personnel. 
Moreover, once again it transpires that the most-cited sour-
ces of information by the dailies were from industry-business,followed by political sources and the administration, civilsociety and finally science, in the minority. Thus, there is a greatflow of information from the private sector related to food, andwhile the political sector enjoys a major presence, it is stillsecond. Nevertheless, it should be remembered that the pre-
dominant type of information source depends on the topic. 
Finally, another interesting thing is the increased proportion
of women cited as a a source of information in food safety.Whereas in 2008 there was a proportion of 1 in 4 versus men,in 2009 46% of people cited as a source of information werewomen, thus furthering their representativeness in this topic. 
• Analysis of the rigour of the information 
In order to study the rigour and degree of scientific evidence ofthe information received by society on food safety questions,we analysed the sources of information used in a specific case.The case chosen was “Food properties”, including functionalfoods, because it is a frequent topic and impacts readers' con-sumption habits. ‘Food properties’ is taken to mean texts thattalk about a certain food or group of foods which ‘naturally’have health-related properties, for example the positive effectsof garlic on blood circulation. Functional foods, on the otherhand, are those in which the producer seeks a beneficial effectfor health, for example milk with omega 3 fatty acids.
The conclusion was that the texts that talked about food
properties are treated in greater depth, with more sources ofinformation, more expert sources, with advice and a moreextensive approach to the question of risk in comparison withfunctional food topics in general. Nevertheless, in both casesserious deficiencies were found in the explanation of possibleconflicts of interests that may exist between the experts citedas a source of information and the different actors that have aninterest in talking positively about a group of foods (companies,cooperatives, etc.). In other words, there was a lack of impor-tant information to enable the reader to be critical about whatthey read.
Animal health
An important part of the 2009 Report is dedicated to topicsrelated to animal health due to the fact that, while they may notbe the most frequent topics, they have had an importantimpact on the perception of food, consumption habits or theeconomy built around this consumption. A specific case thatserved to analyse as a reflection on the importance of commu-nication was what was initially called swine flu and then NewInfluenza, Influenza H1N1 and flu pandemic. The businessworld, administration and media acted synergistically in thiscase. The business world called upon the administration to act,the latter reacted urgently by proposing a change of name, andfinally the media complied with the new recommendations andlost sight of any link between human and swine influenza. Thisrapid strategy, heavily backed by all the actors involved, allayedcitizens' fears regarding the consumption of pork and sparedthe sector from being affected, which had not occurred in otherfood crisis situations (regardless of whether the risk was real ornot). Although the rapid change of name may be defined as acase of good practice, the same cannot be said of the overallcommunication of the Influenza A. La Plataforma SAM (Seguretat Alimentària i Mitjans), és una
iniciativa endegada al gener de 2008 per l’Agència Catalana deSeguretat Alimentària (ACSA), juntament amb l’Observatori deComunicació Científica de la universitat Pompeu Fabra (OCC-UPF). Aquest projecte té per objectiu millorar la capacitat ciu-tadana per prendre decisions sobre la base d’una bona infor-mació.
Per tal d’assolir els seus objectius, la Plataforma SAM inclou
quatre tipus d’activitats:
•Els Informes SAM anuals, on es recull l’anàlisi de la cober-
tura periodística de la seguretat alimentària a l’àmbit deCatalunya. Actualment s’han publicat l’Informe Pilot 2007,l’Informe SAM 2008 i l’Informe SAM 2009 que teniu a lesmans.
•Els Quaderns Monogràfics SAM són publicacions basa-
des en reunions de petit comitè en les quals participenperiodistes i especialistes de les diferents àrees a debat.Fins a aquest moment hem publicat quatre monogràfics:“L’oli com a notícia” (2008), “Organismes ModificatsGenèticament (OMG): un repte de comunicació” (2009),“És segur el que mengem? La seguretat alimentària als mit-jans de comunicació” (2010) i “Volem menjar additius?”(2010).
•La Xarxa SAM , oberta a totes les persones que participen
d’una manera o una altra en la comunicació dels riscs ali-mentaris, entre les quals periodistes de mitjans de comuni-cació i responsables de comunicació a empreses i admi-nistració, gestors i directius, tècnics, investigadors, perso-nal sanitari, veterinaris, ramaders, educadors, represen-tants d’associacions o d’organismes no governamentals, ipersonal de l’administració involucrat en la gestió o lacomunicació del risc alimentari.
•Les Jornades SAM : reunions per tal que els membres d’a-
questa xarxa informal o d’altres persones que hi puguinestar interessades puguin conèixer els resultats de les anà-lisis que es vagin realitzant i comparteixin experiències ireflexions.
